prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PS1-10bzj
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The objective of this Science Goal is recover the dust emission of a low-mass low-metallicty dwarf galaxy that experiences a galaxy-wide starburst. The properties are similar to that of extreme emission-line galaxies.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a continuum-only project to measure the dust luminosity and star-formation rate of a dwarf galaxy that experiences a galaxy wide starburst, so we apply for continuum-mode observations. Given the large uncertainties in the estimate we only want to recover the total flux not to resolve the host.

Deep imaging of the galaxy (from Subaru) shows it to be 0.9 arcsec in total diameter (major axis), which represents the maximum size expected in the submillimeter band also. The desired resolution is based on recovering the total flux not resolving the host.

We are seeking a good S/N of dust continuum from a SLSN host galaxy at z~0.65.
To estimate the r.m.s. level, we use
i) Optical spectroscopy and SED fitting to extract the optical unobscurred star-formation rate (SFR).
ii) Convert the SFR into a dust mass using the relation in Hjorth et al. (2014, ApJ, 782, L23). Specifically we use the black dashed to derive the most conversative estimate on the dust mass.
iii) Convert the dust mass into a flux density at 345 GHz following Michalowski et al. (2009, ApJ, 693, 347). We varied the dust temperature between 40 and 100 K and assumed an emissivity of 1.5 to account for the possible sub-mm excess that has been observed for a number of dwarf galaxies (e.g. Remy-Ruyer et al. 2013, A&A, 557, A95; Galametz et al. 2014, MNRAS, 439, 2542). This approach requires that we probe the Raleigh-Jeans tail of the blackbody, which is valid for redshift of the object.
Specifically, we measured a optical unobscurred SFR of 6.0 +/- 2.3 solar masses per year. This corresponds to a dust mass of 10^6.9-8.1 solar masses and to a minimum flux density of 0.12 mJy (it may be more than if substantial optically-thick star-formation is present). We would like to reach this limit at ~4 sigma confidence level.
The primary goal is to recover the total flux of the host. To achieve this it is not necessary to resolve the host. Therefore the beam size was chosen to be larger than the FWHM of the galaxy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PS1-12zn
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The objective of this Science Goal is recover the dust emission of a low-mass low-metallicty dwarf galaxy that experiences a galaxy-wide starburst.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a continuum-only project to measure the dust luminosity and star-formation rate of a dwarf galaxy that experiences a galaxy wide starburst, so we apply for continuum-mode observations. Given the large uncertainties in the estimate we only want to recover the total flux not to resolve the host.

Deep imaging of the galaxy (from Subaru) shows it to be 1 arcsec in total diameter (major axis), which represents the maximum size expected in the submillimeter band also. The desired resolution is based on recovering the total flux not resolving the host.

We are seeking a good S/N of dust continuum from a SLSN host galaxy at z~0.67.
To estimate the r.m.s. level, we use the same method as for identical to PS1-10bzj.
We measured an optical unobscurred SFR of 6.7 solar masses per year. This corresponds to a dust mass of 10^7.2-8 solar masses and to a minimum flux density of 0.22 mJy (it may be more than if substantial optically-thick star-formation is present). We would like to reach this limit at 5 sigma confidence level.
The primary goal is to recover the total flux of the host. To achieve this it is not necessary to resolve the host. Therefore the beam size was chosen to be larger than the FWHM of the galaxy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SN1999bd
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The objective of this Science Goal is recover the dust emission of a low-mass low-metallicty dwarf galaxy that experiences a galaxy-wide starburst.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a continuum-only project to measure the dust luminosity and star-formation rate of a dwarf galaxy that experiences a galaxy wide starburst, so we apply for continuum-mode observations. Given the large uncertainties in the estimate we only want to recover the total flux not to resolve the host.

Deep imaging of the galaxy (from Magellan) shows it to be 1.9 arcsec in total diameter (major axis), which represents the maximum size expected in the submillimeter band also. The desired resolution is based on recovering the total flux not resolving the host.

We are seeking a good S/N of dust continuum from a SLSN host galaxy at z~0.151.
To estimate the r.m.s. level, we use the same method as for identical to PS1-10bzj.
We measured an optical unobscurred SFR of 1.1 +/- 0.34 solar masses per year (the error includes the uncertainty in the dust correction). This corresponds to a dust mass of 10^6.3-7.3 solar masses and to a minimum flux density of 0.2 mJy (it may be more than if substantial optically-thick star-formation is present). We would like to reach this limit at 5 sigma confidence level.
The primary goal is to recover the total flux of the host. To achieve this it is not necessary to resolve the host. Therefore the beam size was chosen to be larger than the FWHM of the galaxy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The objective of this Science Goal is recover the dust emission of a low-mass low-metallicty dwarf galaxy that experiences a galaxy-wide starburst.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a continuum-only project to measure the dust luminosity and star-formation rate of a dwarf galaxy that experiences a galaxy wide starburst, so we apply for continuum-mode observations. Given the large uncertainties in the estimate we only want to recover the total flux not to resolve the host.

Deep imaging of the galaxy (from Magellan) shows it to be 1.8 arcsec in total diameter (major axis), which represents the maximum size expected in the submillimeter band also. The desired resolution is based on recovering the total flux not resolving the host.

We are seeking a good S/N of dust continuum from a SLSN host galaxy at z~0.284.
To estimate the r.m.s. level, we use the same method as for identical to PS1-10bzj.
We measured an optical unobscurred SFR of 3.1 +/- 0.8 solar masses per year (the error includes the uncertainty in the dust correction). This corresponds to a dust mass of 10^6.8-7.8 solar masses and to a minimum flux density of 0.23 mJy (it may be more than if substantial optically-thick star-formation is present). We would like to reach this limit at 7.7 sigma confidence level.
The primary goal is to recover the total flux of the host. To achieve this it is not necessary to resolve the host. Therefore the beam size was chosen to be larger than the FWHM of the galaxy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The objective of this Science Goal is recover the dust emission of a low-mass low-metallicty dwarf galaxy that experiences a galaxy-wide starburst.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a continuum-only project to measure the dust luminosity and star-formation rate of a dwarf galaxy that experiences a galaxy wide starburst, so we apply for continuum-mode observations. Given the large uncertainties in the estimate we only want to recover the total flux not to resolve the host.

Deep imaging of the galaxy (from Subaru) shows it to be 0.7 arcsec in total diameter (major axis), which represents the maximum size expected in the submillimeter band also. The desired resolution is based on recovering the total flux not resolving the host.

We are seeking a good S/N of dust continuum from a SLSN host galaxy at z~ 3.8993.
To estimate the r.m.s. level, we use the same method as for identical to PS1-10bzj.
We measured an optical unobscurred SFR of 20 +/- 10 solar masses per year (the error includes the uncertainty in the dust correction). This corresponds to a dust mass of 10^7.3-8.6 solar masses and to a minimum flux density of 0.21 mJy (it may be more than if substantial optically-thick star-formation is present). We would like to reach this limit at 5 sigma confidence level.
The primary goal is to recover the total flux of the host. To achieve this it is not necessary to resolve the host. Therefore the beam size was chosen to be larger than the FWHM of the galaxy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SN2213-1745
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The objective of this Science Goal is recover the dust emission of a low-mass low-metallicty dwarf galaxy that experiences a galaxy-wide starburst.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a continuum-only project to measure the dust luminosity and star-formation rate of a dwarf galaxy that experiences a galaxy wide starburst, so we apply for continuum-mode observations. Given the large uncertainties in the estimate we only want to recover the total flux not to resolve the host.

Deep imaging of the galaxy (from CFHT) shows it to be 0.9 arcsec in total diameter (major axis), which represents the maximum size expected in the submillimeter band also. The desired resolution is based on recovering the total flux not resolving the host.

We are seeking a good S/N of dust continuum from a SLSN host galaxy at z~ 2.0458.
To estimate the r.m.s. level, we use the same method as for identical to PS1-10bzj.
We measured an optical unobscurred SFR of 20 +/- 10 solar masses per year (the error includes the uncertainty in the dust correction). This corresponds to a dust mass of 10^7.4-8.7 solar masses and to a minimum flux density of 0.24 mJy (it may be more than if substantial optically-thick star-formation is present). We would like to reach this limit at ~6 sigma confidence level.
The primary goal is to recover the total flux of the host. To achieve this it is not necessary to resolve the host. Therefore the beam size was chosen to be larger than the FWHM of the galaxy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Super-luminous supernovae (SLSNe) are mysterious explosions that challenge our understanding of stellar evolution. During the last years, our team has carried out a systematic survey of host galaxies of SLSNe. We have discovered important differences between the environments of SLSNe of different types, and we have shown that H-poor SLSNe show a preference for young starburst dwarfs, similar to extreme emission-line galaxies. We propose a pilot program to observe six SLSN (4 H-poor and 2 H-rich SLSNe) host galaxies at ~345 GHz to measure the properties of the cold dust component. We will use these data to measure the mass of the cold dust component, search for an obscured starburst in the hosts that evaded detection in the optical, and investigate whether SLSN hosts follow a similar relation between star-formation rate and dust mass similar to ordinary star-forming galaxies. The key of SLSN-selected galaxy studies is that they allow to study galaxies just a few Myr after the starburst in contrast to classical dwarf galaxy samples. These findings will provide a new perspective on extreme epochs in galaxy evolution and offer a new opportunity to study analogues of higher-z starbursts
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: We secured spectra and broadband photometry for most targets. Through ongoing projects we secure missing NIR imaging for the remaining targets (led by Schulze at Magellan, Thone at GTC, Leloudas at the VLT). Some of the proposed targets are also part of a proposed MUSE proposal for P96 (lead by Schulze). The scope of this proposal is to study the galactic environment of super-luminous SN host galaxies and whether galaxy interaction or stochastic process trigger the starburst in these galaxies that give rise to one of nature's most brilliant explosions.
